metadata.purpose: Comprehensive statutory and pattern detection for Systems Integrator contracts
metadata.coverage: UCC Article 2 + Common Law SI Patterns

rules.title: Contractual Modification or Limitation of Remedy

subsections.2-719(1): Agreement may provide for remedies in addition to or substitution for those provided by this Article
subsections.2-719(2): Where circumstances cause an exclusive or limited remedy to fail of its essential purpose, remedy may be had as provided in this title
subsections.2-719(3): Limitation of consequential damages for injury to person in consumer goods is prima facie unconscionable

forensic_logic.primary_test: Does the clause create a 'failure of essential purpose' by removing all meaningful remedies?
forensic_logic.si_concern: If vendor's remedy fails, can you still recover to satisfy your client obligations?

cascade_detection.pattern: If prepayment is mandatory AND withholding is restricted AND termination credits are absent, flag as illusory remedy

key_indicators: Withholding restricted to 'explicitly documented' criteria only
No credit or refund upon early termination
Cure period extends beyond prepayment consumption

rules.business_impact: Client loses all self-help remedies; vendor holds unilateral control over dispute resolution
rules.si_impact: If vendor equipment fails, your only remedy may be worthless repair promises while client demands performance

rules.title: Unconscionable Contract or Clause

subsections.2-302(1): Court may refuse to enforce contract or clause found unconscionable at time made
subsections.2-302(2): Parties shall be afforded reasonable opportunity to present evidence as to commercial setting, purpose, and effect

forensic_logic.primary_test: Does the clause create gross disparity in bargaining position or impose terms no reasonable person would accept?
forensic_logic.si_concern: OEM standard terms often heavily favor vendor - are you accepting unconscionable terms you'll have to pass to your client?

cumulative_analysis.description: If 3+ limitation clauses combine to eliminate all client remedies, cumulative effect may be unconscionable
combination_patterns: Prepayment + Restricted Withholding + Gross Negligence Standard
No Liability + Sole Discretion + Unilateral Termination
Waiver of Damages + Force Performance + No Refund

rules.business_impact: Contract or clause may be unenforceable; litigation risk elevated
rules.si_impact: Terms you accept from vendors may not be enforceable, leaving you without recourse

rules.title: Deduction of Damages from the Price

subsections.2-717: Buyer on notifying seller of intention to do so may deduct all or any part of the damages resulting from any breach of contract from any part of the price still due under the same contract

forensic_logic.primary_test: Does the clause waive the buyer's statutory right to deduct damages from amounts owed?
forensic_logic.si_concern: If you can't withhold from vendors when they breach, you're financing their failures while still owing your client

cascade_detection.pattern: If buyer cannot deduct AND indemnification is delayed, buyer finances vendor's breach

rules.business_impact: Client must finance vendor defaults; cash flow risk and litigation burden shifted to buyer
rules.si_impact: You pay vendor 100%, vendor breaches, you sue to recover while simultaneously owing client credits

rules.title: Liquidation or Limitation of Damages; Deposits

subsections.2-718(1): Damages for breach may be liquidated but only at amount reasonable in light of anticipated or actual harm
subsections.2-718(2): Where seller justifiably withholds delivery, buyer is entitled to restitution of amount by which sum paid exceeds reasonable liquidated damages

forensic_logic.primary_test: Are liquidated damages reasonable in light of anticipated harm, or do they constitute an unenforceable penalty?
forensic_logic.si_concern: Compare vendor LD exposure to client LD exposure - is there a gap you absorb?
reasonableness_factors: Anticipated harm at time of contracting
key_indicators: Liquidated damages exceed 20% of contract value
Same damages apply regardless of breach severity
Forfeiture of all prepaid amounts regardless of work completed

rules.business_impact: Penalty clauses may be unenforceable; excessive fees create negotiation leverage
rules.si_impact: Client LD of $50K/day but vendor LD capped at $10K total = $40K/day exposure

rules.title: Statute of Limitations in Contracts for Sale

subsections.2-725(1): Action for breach must be commenced within four years after cause of action accrued
subsections.2-725(2): Parties may reduce period of limitation to not less than one year but may not extend it

forensic_logic.primary_test: Does the clause improperly shorten or attempt to extend the statutory limitation period?
forensic_logic.si_concern: Vendor claims period shorter than client claims period = latent defect exposure

valid_range.note: Periods shorter than 1 year or longer than 4 years are unenforceable

rules.business_impact: Artificially shortened periods may bar legitimate claims; unenforceable if below 1 year
rules.si_impact: Client can claim for 4 years, vendor limits you to 1 year = 3 years unprotected

rules.title: Warranty of Title and Against Infringement

subsections.2-312(1): Seller warrants good title, rightful transfer, goods free from security interest or lien unknown to buyer
subsections.2-312(2): Seller who is a merchant warrants goods are delivered free of rightful claim of infringement
subsections.2-312(3): Warranty can be excluded or modified only by specific language or circumstances

forensic_logic.primary_test: Does the equipment come with clear title? Are there liens or IP claims?
forensic_logic.si_concern: If vendor equipment has liens or IP claims, your client's system is at risk

rules.business_impact: Equipment could be repossessed or enjoined for IP infringement
rules.si_impact: Client's warehouse shuts down due to patent injunction on conveyor system you installed

rules.title: Express Warranties by Affirmation

subsections.2-313(1)(a): Affirmation of fact or promise made by seller to buyer which relates to goods and becomes part of basis of bargain creates express warranty
subsections.2-313(1)(b): Description of goods which is made part of basis of bargain creates express warranty
subsections.2-313(1)(c): Sample or model which is made part of basis of bargain creates express warranty
subsections.2-313(2): No need for formal words like 'warrant' or 'guarantee' or specific intention to make warranty

forensic_logic.primary_test: What specific performance claims has vendor made that constitute express warranties?
forensic_logic.si_concern: You may be guaranteeing system performance based on vendor's express warranties - are they protected?
key_indicators: Reference to data sheets or specifications

rules.business_impact: Vendor bound by performance claims in sales materials and proposals
rules.si_impact: You guarantee client 500 units/hour based on vendor spec; equipment delivers 400 = your liability

rules.title: Implied Warranty of Merchantability

subsections.2-314(1): Warranty of merchantability is implied in contract for sale if seller is merchant with respect to goods of that kind
subsections.2-314(2)(a): Goods must pass without objection in trade under contract description
subsections.2-314(2)(c): Goods must be fit for ordinary purposes for which such goods are used

forensic_logic.primary_test: Has the implied warranty of merchantability been disclaimed? If so, was it conspicuous?
forensic_logic.si_concern: AS IS equipment may not be fit for warehouse integration purposes
key_indicators: AS IS language in caps or bold

rules.business_impact: Equipment must be fit for ordinary purpose unless properly disclaimed
rules.si_impact: Conveyor sold 'AS IS' breaks down; no warranty recourse but client expects working system

rules.title: Implied Warranty of Fitness for Particular Purpose

subsections.2-315: Where seller at time of contracting has reason to know particular purpose for which goods are required and that buyer is relying on seller's skill or judgment to select or furnish suitable goods, there is implied warranty goods shall be fit for such purpose

forensic_logic.primary_test: Did vendor know your specific application? Did you rely on their recommendation?
forensic_logic.si_concern: If vendor recommended equipment for your client's specific application, they warrant fitness
key_indicators: Specific throughput or environmental requirements disclosed

rules.business_impact: Vendor liable if equipment unsuitable for disclosed particular purpose
rules.si_impact: Vendor knew it was for cold storage; equipment fails at -20°F = vendor liability

rules.title: Exclusion or Modification of Warranties

subsections.2-316(1): Words or conduct tending to negate warranty shall be construed wherever reasonable as consistent with each other
subsections.2-316(2): To exclude merchantability, language must mention merchantability and be conspicuous; to exclude fitness, exclusion must be in writing and conspicuous
subsections.2-316(3)(a): AS IS, WITH ALL FAULTS or similar language excludes implied warranties
subsections.2-316(3)(b): Examination or refusal to examine excludes defects that examination should have revealed

forensic_logic.primary_test: Is the warranty disclaimer conspicuous? Does it specifically mention merchantability?
forensic_logic.si_concern: Invalid warranty disclaimers may give you more protection than contract appears to provide
key_indicators: Merchantability not specifically mentioned (invalid for merchantability)
AS IS not conspicuous (may be invalid)

rules.business_impact: Improper disclaimer = warranties still exist despite contract language
rules.si_impact: Vendor's buried disclaimer may be unenforceable - you may have warranty rights you think you waived

rules.title: Additional Terms in Acceptance or Confirmation

subsections.2-207(1): Definite expression of acceptance operates as acceptance even with additional or different terms
subsections.2-207(2): Additional terms become part of contract between merchants unless materially alter, offer limits acceptance, or objection given
subsections.2-207(3): Conduct recognizing contract existence is sufficient even without writings establishing contract

forensic_logic.primary_test: Whose terms govern - your PO or vendor's acknowledgment?
forensic_logic.si_concern: Vendor acknowledgment with different warranty/liability terms may become binding
key_indicators: Your PO silent on which terms prevail
No objection to vendor's additional terms

rules.business_impact: Vendor's terms may silently become binding through battle of forms
rules.si_impact: Your PO had full warranties; vendor acknowledgment disclaimed them; silence = vendor terms win

rules.title: Right to Adequate Assurance of Performance

subsections.2-609(1): When reasonable grounds for insecurity arise, party may demand adequate assurance and suspend performance until received
subsections.2-609(2): Between merchants, reasonableness of grounds and adequacy of assurance determined by commercial standards
subsections.2-609(4): Failure to provide adequate assurance within reasonable time (not exceeding 30 days) is repudiation

forensic_logic.primary_test: Does contract preserve your right to demand assurance if vendor shows signs of trouble?
forensic_logic.si_concern: If vendor is struggling (missed deliveries, financial issues), can you demand assurance?
key_indicators: Waiver of right to demand assurance
No right to suspend for reasonable grounds

rules.business_impact: Right to demand proof vendor can perform before you're committed
rules.si_impact: Vendor misses first milestone; you can demand assurance before paying next invoice

rules.title: Anticipatory Repudiation

subsections.2-610(a): When either party repudiates, aggrieved party may await performance for commercially reasonable time
subsections.2-610(b): Aggrieved party may resort to any remedy for breach even if notified willingness to retract repudiation
subsections.2-610(c): Aggrieved party may suspend own performance or identify goods to contract

forensic_logic.primary_test: What rights do you have if vendor indicates they won't or can't perform?
forensic_logic.si_concern: Vendor announces equipment is discontinued mid-project - what are your rights?
key_indicators: No right to terminate for anticipatory breach
Must continue performance despite vendor repudiation
Force majeure extends to voluntary discontinuation

rules.business_impact: Right to act immediately when vendor signals breach
rules.si_impact: Vendor says they're exiting the market; you can source elsewhere immediately

rules.title: Buyer's Rights on Improper Delivery

subsections.2-601(a): If goods fail to conform to contract in any respect, buyer may reject the whole
subsections.2-601(c): Buyer may accept any commercial unit or units and reject the rest

forensic_logic.primary_test: Can you reject non-conforming equipment, or must you accept and sue?
forensic_logic.si_concern: If conveyor arrives damaged, can you reject or must you accept and repair?
key_indicators: Must accept with price adjustment only

rules.business_impact: Right to reject defective goods entirely
rules.si_impact: Robot arrives non-functional; rejection right lets you refuse and source elsewhere

rules.title: What Constitutes Acceptance of Goods

subsections.2-606(1)(a): Acceptance occurs when buyer after reasonable opportunity to inspect signifies goods are conforming or will take despite non-conformity
subsections.2-606(1)(b): Acceptance occurs when buyer fails to make effective rejection after reasonable opportunity to inspect
subsections.2-606(1)(c): Acceptance occurs when buyer does any act inconsistent with seller's ownership

forensic_logic.primary_test: When does acceptance occur? How much time do you have to inspect?
forensic_logic.si_concern: Equipment installed in client's facility may trigger acceptance before full testing

rules.business_impact: Once accepted, rejection rights are lost
rules.si_impact: Conveyor installed, then discovered defective; acceptance locks you in

rules.title: Effect of Acceptance; Notice of Breach

subsections.2-607(2): Acceptance of goods by buyer precludes rejection of goods accepted
subsections.2-607(3)(a): Buyer must notify seller of breach within reasonable time after discovery or be barred from remedy

forensic_logic.primary_test: What notice must you give and when to preserve your claims?
forensic_logic.si_concern: Defect discovered 6 months after installation - did you notify in time?

rules.business_impact: Late notice = lost remedy
rules.si_impact: Defect discovered, but notice 5 days late = no warranty claim

rules.title: Revocation of Acceptance

subsections.2-608(1)(a): Buyer may revoke acceptance if non-conformity substantially impairs value and acceptance was on reasonable assumption non-conformity would be cured and has not been
subsections.2-608(1)(b): Buyer may revoke acceptance if non-conformity substantially impairs value and acceptance was without discovery of non-conformity due to difficulty of discovery or seller's assurances
subsections.2-608(2): Revocation must occur within reasonable time after buyer discovers or should have discovered grounds

forensic_logic.primary_test: Can you return equipment if latent defect substantially impairs value?
forensic_logic.si_concern: Equipment accepted, then major defect found - can you revoke?

rules.business_impact: Safety valve for latent defects discovered post-acceptance
rules.si_impact: Conveyor accepted, then motor design flaw discovered; revocation lets you return

rules.title: Excuse by Failure of Presupposed Conditions

subsections.2-615(a): Delay or non-delivery not breach if performance made impracticable by occurrence of contingency non-occurrence of which was basic assumption
subsections.2-615(b): If only part of capacity affected, seller must allocate production fairly among customers
subsections.2-615(c): Seller must seasonably notify buyer of delay or non-delivery

forensic_logic.primary_test: When can vendor be excused from performance? Is it narrowly defined?
forensic_logic.si_concern: If vendor claims force majeure, are you also excused to your client?
key_indicators: Force majeure doesn't flow down to your client contract

rules.business_impact: Vendor escapes performance for unforeseeable events
rules.si_impact: Vendor claims chip shortage = FM excuse; your client contract has no FM clause = your liability

rules.title: Warranty Flow-Down Gap

subsections.description: Vendor warranty period shorter than client warranty creates unprotected exposure window

forensic_logic.primary_test: Is vendor warranty period >= client warranty period?
forensic_logic.si_concern: You warrant to client for 24 months; vendor warrants to you for 12 months = 12 months unprotected

rules.business_impact: Warranty claims in gap period are 100% your liability
rules.si_impact: Client claims warranty at month 18; vendor warranty expired at month 12 = your cost

rules.title: Liability Cap Squeeze

subsections.description: Vendor liability cap lower than your client liability exposure creates uninsured gap

forensic_logic.primary_test: Is vendor liability cap >= your client liability exposure?
forensic_logic.si_concern: Client can claim $5M from you; vendor cap is $500K = $4.5M unrecoverable
key_indicators: Vendor cap is % of contract value

rules.business_impact: Liability exposure beyond recovery from vendor
rules.si_impact: You owe client $2M; vendor cap is $200K; you absorb $1.8M

rules.title: Indemnification Asymmetry

subsections.description: You indemnify client for vendor issues, but vendor won't indemnify you

forensic_logic.primary_test: Does vendor indemnify you for same things you indemnify client?
forensic_logic.si_concern: You indemnify client for IP infringement; vendor provides no IP indemnity = your exposure
key_indicators: Your indemnification is broader than vendor's

rules.business_impact: Pass-through liability without pass-through protection
rules.si_impact: Client sues you for patent infringement; vendor provides no defense or indemnity

rules.title: IP Ownership Grab

subsections.description: Contract assigns your integration IP to client or vendor without license back

forensic_logic.primary_test: Who owns the integration work product? Do you retain rights to your methodology?
forensic_logic.si_concern: Client claims ownership of your integration methodology, blocking reuse

rules.business_impact: Loss of reusable intellectual property
rules.si_impact: Integration approach you developed becomes client's exclusive property

rules.title: Acceptance Trap

subsections.description: Vague or impossible acceptance criteria combined with payment holdback creates never-ending project

forensic_logic.primary_test: Are acceptance criteria objectively measurable? Is there deemed acceptance?
forensic_logic.si_concern: Client withholds final payment claiming 'not accepted' with subjective criteria
key_indicators: Acceptance tied to client's client acceptance

rules.business_impact: Payment indefinitely withheld pending subjective acceptance
rules.si_impact: System works perfectly but client won't sign acceptance = 20% retainage held indefinitely

rules.title: Change Order Lockout

subsections.description: Restrictive change order process makes getting paid for extra work nearly impossible

forensic_logic.primary_test: Can you get paid for out-of-scope work requested verbally?
forensic_logic.si_concern: Client directs extra work, refuses to sign change order, won't pay
key_indicators: No work without signed change order
Client can direct changes without price adjustment

rules.business_impact: Unpaid scope creep
rules.si_impact: Client directs $200K of extra work verbally; no signed CO = no payment

rules.title: Performance Guarantee Pass-Through Failure

subsections.description: You guarantee system performance dependent on vendor equipment without matching vendor guarantee

forensic_logic.primary_test: Are your performance guarantees to client backed by vendor guarantees?
forensic_logic.si_concern: You guarantee 99.5% uptime; vendor warrants 'commercially reasonable efforts' = gap
key_indicators: No performance LD in vendor contract

rules.business_impact: Performance liability without recourse
rules.si_impact: System achieves 97% uptime; client claims $500K LD; vendor has no LD = your loss

rules.title: Insurance Gap

subsections.description: Liability exposure exceeds insurance coverage or vendor has insufficient coverage

forensic_logic.primary_test: Is total liability exposure covered by insurance (yours + vendor's)?
forensic_logic.si_concern: Contract liability exceeds your coverage; vendor won't add you as additional insured
key_indicators: No professional liability requirement for vendor
Not named as additional insured on vendor policy

rules.business_impact: Uninsured liability exposure
rules.si_impact: Claim exceeds your $5M coverage; vendor has only $1M = $4M uninsured

cascade_patterns.name: The Prepayment Trap
cascade_patterns.description: Mandatory prepayment combined with restricted withholding creates illusory remedy

components.element: Withholding restricted to documented SOW criteria
Termination requires cure period exceeding prepayment consumption

cascade_patterns.remediation: Add escrow mechanism or milestone-based release for prepaid amounts

cascade_patterns.name: The Indemnification Collapse
cascade_patterns.description: Elevated negligence standard combined with no set-off eliminates practical recovery
cascade_patterns.remediation: Restore ordinary negligence standard or add carve-outs

cascade_patterns.name: The Remedy Veto
cascade_patterns.description: Cumulative limitations that collectively eliminate all meaningful remedies
cascade_patterns.remediation: Add UCC preservation clause for failure of essential purpose

cascade_patterns.name: The Warranty Gap
cascade_patterns.description: Vendor warranty shorter than client warranty creates unprotected window
cascade_patterns.remediation: Negotiate vendor warranty >= client warranty, or purchase extended warranty

cascade_patterns.name: The Liability Squeeze
cascade_patterns.description: Vendor liability cap lower than client exposure creates unrecoverable gap
cascade_patterns.remediation: Negotiate vendor cap matching client exposure, or add insurance carve-out

cascade_patterns.name: The Acceptance Trap
cascade_patterns.description: Vague acceptance criteria combined with high retainage creates indefinite payment hold
cascade_patterns.remediation: Add objective acceptance criteria, deemed acceptance after 30 days, reduce retainage

cascade_patterns.name: The IP Grab
cascade_patterns.description: Work for hire combined with no license back eliminates reuse of your methodology

components.element: No license back for internal use

cascade_patterns.remediation: Add pre-existing IP carve-out, perpetual license back for methodologies

cascade_patterns.name: The Change Order Lockout
cascade_patterns.description: Strict change order requirements combined with client direction creates unpaid work

components.element: No work without signed change order
Client can direct work pending approval

cascade_patterns.remediation: Add constructive change clause, automatic price adjustment for directed changes

cascade_patterns.name: The Performance Guarantee Gap
cascade_patterns.description: System performance guarantee without matching vendor equipment guarantee
cascade_patterns.remediation: Negotiate vendor performance guarantee matching client requirements, or LD flow-down

cascade_patterns.name: The Force Majeure Gap
cascade_patterns.description: Vendor has broad FM excuse but you have narrow or no FM protection to client

components.element: Narrow or no force majeure clause

cascade_patterns.remediation: Add FM flow-through to client contract, or require vendor FM to excuse your client obligations

cascade_patterns.name: The Battle of Forms Trap
cascade_patterns.description: Your PO terms overwritten by vendor acknowledgment terms through silence
cascade_patterns.remediation: Add 'PO terms prevail' clause, require written objection to all vendor modifications

cascade_patterns.name: The Warranty Disclaimer Bypass
cascade_patterns.description: Vendor disclaims warranties but disclaimer may be unenforceable
cascade_patterns.remediation: Challenge validity of disclaimer; may have warranty rights despite contract language

boilerplate_redlines.prepayment_escrow: All prepaid amounts exceeding $5,000 shall be held in joint escrow and released only upon Client's written acceptance of deliverables.
boilerplate_redlines.defined_acceptance: Acceptance criteria for all deliverables shall be documented in Exhibit A prior to any prepayment. General quality standards (industry best practices, workmanlike manner, fitness for purpose) shall apply in absence of specific criteria.
boilerplate_redlines.ucc_preservation: Nothing in this Agreement shall be construed to limit Client's remedies under the Delaware Uniform Commercial Code § 2-719 if any limited remedy fails of its essential purpose.
boilerplate_redlines.ordinary_negligence_carveout: Notwithstanding the foregoing, Vendor shall indemnify Client for losses arising from Vendor's ordinary negligence to the extent covered by Vendor's commercial general liability insurance.
boilerplate_redlines.setoff_rights: Client may deduct from amounts due any damages resulting from Vendor's breach, upon written notice to Vendor specifying the breach and damages claimed.
boilerplate_redlines.warranty_flowdown: Vendor warrants that all warranties provided hereunder shall extend for a period no less than [CLIENT WARRANTY PERIOD] from final system acceptance by Client's end customer.
boilerplate_redlines.liability_cap_match: Vendor's aggregate liability under this Agreement shall not be less than the aggregate liability cap in Client's end customer contract, or $[AMOUNT], whichever is greater.
boilerplate_redlines.ip_carveout: Notwithstanding any assignment provisions, Client's pre-existing intellectual property, methodologies, tools, and know-how shall remain Client's exclusive property, with a perpetual license to end customer for use with the delivered system only.
boilerplate_redlines.deemed_acceptance: If end customer fails to provide written notice of non-conformance within [30] days of substantial completion, the deliverables shall be deemed accepted.
boilerplate_redlines.constructive_change: If end customer directs work outside the original scope, Client may proceed with such work and shall be entitled to equitable adjustment in price and schedule, whether or not a formal change order is executed.
boilerplate_redlines.performance_flowdown: Vendor warrants that equipment shall meet or exceed the performance specifications in Exhibit B, which specifications are derived from Client's commitments to end customer.
boilerplate_redlines.fm_flowdown: Any force majeure event excusing Vendor's performance shall automatically excuse Client's corresponding obligations to its end customer. Vendor's force majeure shall not apply to payment obligations.
